ab_plaque: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared 5xFAD transgenic mouse brain labeled for amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques. The staining produces dense, bright fluorescent deposits scattered throughout the parenchyma, with rounded or irregularly shaped aggregates. These extracellular plaques appear as high-contrast puncta and clusters in the 640 nm channel, marking hallmark Alzheimer's disease pathology in cortical and hippocampal regions.
astrocytes: In this mouse brain imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) immunolabeling reveals star-shaped astrocytic cell bodies and intricate filamentous processes. The signal appears as bright, branching fluorescent fibers that weave through the tissue, forming a complex three-dimensional network that stands out clearly from the surrounding background.
cfos: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared mouse brain immunolabeled for the activity-dependent protein c-Fos. The antibody staining yields bright punctate nuclear signals marking recently activated neurons. In the 640 nm channel, c-Fos-positive cells appear as distinct, sharply outlined nuclei distributed across cortical and subcortical regions, standing out against a dark background of unstained tissue.
chondrocytes: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared human embryo head (PCW7-11) immunolabeled for Collagen II. The signal appears as bright, continuous mesh-like fluorescence outlining cartilage matrix and surrounding chondrocytes. Collagen II-positive structures form well-organized bands and sheets of signal in developing cranial cartilage, with a dense, glowing extracellular pattern that contrasts with adjacent unlabeled tissue.
chondrogenic_cells: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared human embryo head (PCW5-11) immunolabeled for Sox9. Sox9-positive progenitors appear as clusters of brightly fluorescent nuclei within mesenchymal condensations. The signal is punctate and localized to nuclear regions, highlighting early chondrogenic cell populations before cartilage matrix formation, with sharp contrast against surrounding mesenchyme.
ctip2_neurons: In a cleared mouse brain imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling for CTIP2 (BCL11B) marks deep-layer cortical projection neurons, particularly in layer V. The stain produces bright, nuclear and perinuclear fluorescence within these neurons, forming dense clusters of glowing somata in the lower cortical layers and scattered signal in subcortical projection regions. The labeled cells stand out sharply from the surrounding tissue, revealing the laminar organization of CTIP2-positive neurons in three dimensions.
lyve1_lymphatic_vessel: In the cleared mouse brain, immunolabeling for LYVE1 highlights slender, branching fluorescent vessels that trace the pathways of the meningeal and perivascular lymphatic network. Viewed with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, these delicate tubular structures appear as continuous glowing strands outlining the brain’s lymphatic architecture in three dimensions.
nf_peripheral_nerve: In the cleared mouse head, neurofilament (NF) immunolabeling reveals bright, thread-like fluorescent fibers representing peripheral nerves. The labeled axons appear as fine, elongated strands coursing through brain-adjacent tissues, forming a distinct filamentous network visible in three dimensions under light-sheet fluorescence microscopy.
nucleus: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a post-mortem adult human brain cleared with the SHANEL protocol and stained with propidium iodide (PI). The nuclei appear as bright, sharply defined red spheres or ovals, densely distributed across both gray and white matter. The PI signal creates a speckled fluorescent pattern where each glowing dot corresponds to an individual nucleus, enabling three-dimensional mapping of cell density across thick tissue.
p75_nerves: In the cleared mouse head imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling for the p75 neurotrophin receptor (p75 NTR) highlights peripheral and cranial nerves with strong, continuous fluorescence. The labeled fibers appear as smooth, tubular fluorescent strands tracing nerve pathways through the tissue, often running in parallel bundles. This staining delineates the glowing trajectories of peripheral nerves and their branching patterns in three dimensions.
pgp_peripheral_nerve: In the cleared mouse head, PGP9.5 immunolabeling outlines bright, slender fluorescent fibers corresponding to cranial and peripheral nerves. These smooth, thread-like strands run through brain-adjacent tissues and along the skull base, forming a clear three-dimensional network of nerve projections visible under light-sheet fluorescence microscopy.
sma_artery: In the cleared mouse head imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling for smooth muscle actin (SMA) highlights arterial walls as bright, continuous tubular structures. The signal forms thick, glowing vessels that branch into smaller arterioles, showing the smooth, layered morphology characteristic of muscular arteries. These fluorescent tubes trace the three-dimensional architecture of the arterial network, standing out clearly against the surrounding tissue.
th_neurons: Immunolabeling for tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) in light-sheet fluorescence microscopy reveals bright, fluorescent neuronal somata and slender processes characteristic of dopaminergic and noradrenergic cells. The labeled neurons form distinct clusters of glowing cell bodies with projecting fibers visible in three dimensions, delineating catecholaminergic populations across midbrain and brainstem regions.
th_sympathetic_nerve: In the cleared mouse head imaged with light-sheet fluorescence microscopy, immunolabeling for tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) reveals bright, thin fluorescent fibers corresponding to sympathetic nerves. These labeled axons form delicate, branching networks that follow blood vessels and peripheral pathways. The staining produces fine, glowing filaments that trace the distribution of catecholaminergic innervation in three dimensions.
vessel_eb: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared adult mouse brain labeled with Evans Blue (EB). EB staining produces intensely bright, tubular fluorescence confined to large-caliber blood vessels. The dye fills arteries and veins, appearing as thick, glowing red tracks through the tissue, with high signal intensity in major vessels such as the middle cerebral artery and circle of Willis.
vessel_wga: Light-sheet fluorescence microscopy image patch of a cleared adult mouse brain perfused with wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) conjugated to Alexa Fluor 594. The WGA staining highlights microvessels and capillaries as fine, thread-like fluorescent networks spreading densely through the parenchyma. In the 561 nm channel, these thin glowing filaments form a delicate, lace-like pattern that reveals the dense microvascular bed at high resolution.
